home.title: Free Sleep Test — get your personalized report (beta)
home.pitch: Answer 30 quick questions in 5–10 minutes. No cost, no registration. Get a clear, science-based report with explanations and practical tips.
home.tests_count_caption: people have already tested their sleep with this free, anonymous tool.

card.title: Anonymous and 100% free
card.text: We take GDPR personally: no registration, no logging, no cost — all anonymous.

card.title: Track your progress
card.text: Take the test again later and compare your results over time.

compare.help: Do you have your previous ID? Enter both to see progress — and where.
compare.notfound: Could not find one or both IDs.
compare.error: Something went wrong. Please try again.
compare.explainer: Compare two reports to see if your actions are working. We recommend retesting every 4–8 weeks so you can clearly see the trend over time.

result.title: Result
result.disclaimer: This is not a medical evaluation, but a general guide to help you notice patterns and try practical steps. Sleep habits often change gradually — experiment, be patient, and see what works best for you.

lead.orange: You have room for improvement in
lead.red: You should change your habits for

result.lookup_hint: When you complete a test you receive an ID. It is anonymous, and you can open your report anytime. Paste your ID to view the report.

suggestions.title: Improvement areas
suggestions.subtitle: Your result is based on your answers—focus on what feels relevant to you.

result.share_message_with_score: I took a free sleep test and scored {score}/100. Try your own anonymous test:
result.share_message: I took a free sleep test. Try your own anonymous test:

card.title: Sleep tips & knowledge
card.text: Explore practical sleep guides — covering routines, insomnia, sleep hygiene, and more. Written for the general public, based on credible research.

pattern.title: Sleep pattern & duration: a routine that works
pattern.teaser: Why regular hours and enough time in bed make everything easier—plus simple steps to start tonight.

insomnia.title: Trouble falling or staying asleep
insomnia.teaser: CBT-I for real life: the 20-minute rule, stimulus control, and why a fixed wake time matters.

quality.title: Sleep quality: lifting the overall feel
quality.teaser: What “quality” really means, common drags on it, and how to nudge it upward steadily.

daytime.title: Daytime & sleepiness: more alert hours
daytime.teaser: Morning light, micro-movement breaks, and better timing for less dozing and more focus.

hygiene.title: Sleep hygiene and routines that actually help
hygiene.teaser: Screen-light evenings, a caffeine cut-off, and a simple wind-down—without the guilt.

environment.title: Sleep environment: light, noise, temperature & bed
environment.teaser: Low-cost tweaks for calmer nights—blackout, sound, and a pillow that really fits.

breathing.title: Snoring & breathing signals: when to check it
breathing.teaser: When snoring is harmless, when it might be sleep apnea, and what to do next.

summaries.some: Popular TikTok and Reddit sleep hacks weighed against science – plus a ranked toolbox to help you fall asleep.
summaries.pattern: Why regular timing and enough sleep matter – plus simple fixes that work.
summaries.insomnia: Practical ways to fall asleep faster and handle nighttime wake-ups.
summaries.quality: Reduce common disrupters and make nights calmer and deeper.
summaries.daytime: Light, movement and micro-breaks: stay alert and function better.
summaries.hygiene: Screens, caffeine, alcohol and wind-down: habits that truly help.
summaries.environment: Light, noise, temperature and bed: build a room that supports sleep.
summaries.breathing: When snoring is a warning sign and what to do next.

about.title: Created by DMZ DATA AS
about.intro: Built almost without effort in Porsgrunn, combining healthtech/sleeptech and AI.

contact.title: Contact
contact.p1: Responsible for www.sleep-test.org is DMZ DATA AS. Contact point for privacy inquiries and general questions: kontor@dmz.no.
contact.p2: Explore DMZ DATA wonders at www.dmz.no, an app to learn Google web search (LINK), an app to learn ChatGPT (LINK), and make your Homey smart home a bit more fun with DadJokes (LINK).

privacy.title: Privacy Policy
privacy.p1: We take privacy seriously. This policy explains how we handle information when you use www.sleep-test.org. By using the site, you confirm that you have read and accepted these terms. The site is designed so that schools can use it without providing any personal information.
privacy.li1: What data we process: We do not collect names, email addresses, or other directly identifiable information. To display and remember results, only a system-generated ID is stored together with a summary of answers. We do not use marketing cookies, third-party tracking scripts, or profiling.
privacy.li2: Purpose and legal basis: The purpose is to provide the service and improve its quality. The legal basis is legitimate interest (GDPR art. 6(1)(f)) in operating a secure and functional solution without processing personal data. Technical logs may be processed for troubleshooting and security.
privacy.li3: Storage and deletion: Technical IDs and result summaries are stored only as long as necessary for the stated purpose. If you believe content should be deleted, you can contact us at kontor@dmz.no.
privacy.li4: Sharing and transfer: We do not share data with third parties. If we use subcontractors (data processors) for operations, they will be contractually obliged to protect data and not use it for their own purposes.
privacy.li5: School use and children: The service can be used in schools without providing student data. Teachers and students can read and use the site without registration. No personal data is processed beyond what is strictly necessary for technical operation.
privacy.li6: Cookies: We do not use unnecessary cookies. If we in the future introduce functional cookies (e.g., for language preference), we will update this policy and request consent where required.
privacy.li7: Your rights and contact: If you have questions, wish to access technical information, or request deletion, contact us at kontor@dmz.no. You can also lodge a complaint with the Norwegian Data Protection Authority (Datatilsynet).
privacy.li8: Changes: We may update this policy when needed. Significant changes will be published here.

common.error_submit: Could not submit. Please try again.

bloodpressure.name: Blood pressure – lifestyle risk
bloodpressure.desc: Diet, activity, alcohol, stress, and weight.

pattern.too_short: I sleep less than I need most nights.
pattern.irregular_times: My sleep times vary a lot from day to day.
pattern.late_long_naps: I take long or late naps that disturb the night.

insomnia.long_sleep_onset: It takes me a long time to fall asleep after going to bed.
insomnia.frequent_awakenings: I wake up several times during the night.
insomnia.early_morning_awakenings: I wake too early and can’t get back to sleep.
insomnia.unrefreshed_mornings: I don’t feel refreshed in the morning.
insomnia.daytime_impact: My sleep problems affect my daytime functioning (mood, focus, energy).

quality.overall_poor: My overall experience of sleep is often poor.
quality.dissatisfied: I am dissatisfied with my sleep.
quality.restless_nights: My nights are often restless (nightmares, restlessness, pain).

daytime.doze_easily: I doze easily in calm situations (TV, reading, passenger).
daytime.struggle_stay_awake: I struggle to stay awake when I must concentrate.
daytime.tired_most_day: I fight tiredness for large parts of the day.

hygiene.screens_before_bed: I use screens right before bedtime.
hygiene.late_caffeine: I drink coffee/energy drinks late in the day.
hygiene.big_meal_late: I eat large meals late in the evening.
hygiene.hard_exercise_late: I exercise hard right before bedtime.

environment.too_light_noise_temp: The bedroom is often too bright, noisy or the wrong temperature.
environment.uncomfortable_bed: The bed or pillow is uncomfortable.
environment.bad_associations: I work/watch TV in bed and get poor sleep associations.

breathing.observed_apneas: Others have observed breathing pauses when I sleep.
breathing.daytime_tired_despite: I’m very sleepy in the daytime even after a normal night.

bloodpressure.diet_salty: I often eat foods high in salt (e.g., ready meals, snacks, salty spreads).
bloodpressure.activity_low: I am not very physically active in daily life.
bloodpressure.alcohol_often: I drink alcohol more often or in larger amounts than recommended.
bloodpressure.stress_high: I experience a lot of stress in everyday life.

flags.osa_signal: Possible signs of sleep apnea – consider talking to your doctor.
flags.excessive_sleepiness: Marked daytime sleepiness – be extra careful.
flags.high_bp_risk: Several lifestyle factors point to an increased risk of high blood pressure. Consider measuring your blood pressure when you have the opportunity, especially if you have type 2 diabetes or close relatives with cardiovascular disease.

keep_routine.title: Keep your current rhythm
keep_routine.desc: Fixed bed and wake times are working—stick with them.

protect_7h.title: Protect at least 7 hours in bed
protect_7h.desc: Block enough time so sleep pressure can build and you can recover.

consistent_bed_wake.title: Regular bed and wake windows
consistent_bed_wake.desc: Aim for roughly the same hours every day, even on weekends.

plan_winddown.title: Plan a 20–30 minute wind-down
plan_winddown.desc: Dim lights, screens off, and do something calm before bed.

cut_late_naps.title: Skip late naps
cut_late_naps.desc: Avoid napping after mid-afternoon so you’re sleepy at night.

maintain.title: Keep the helpful habits
maintain.desc: You’re handling awakenings well—keep the routine steady.

rule_20min.title: 20-minute rule
rule_20min.desc: If you can’t sleep, get up briefly and reset with a calm activity.

fixed_wake.title: Fixed wake time
fixed_wake.desc: Wake at the same time daily to retrain your sleep drive.

stimulus_control.title: Bed = sleep
stimulus_control.desc: Use the bed only for sleep and intimacy; move elsewhere when awake.

consider_cbti.title: Consider CBT-I
consider_cbti.desc: If insomnia persists, a CBT-I program or clinician can help.

track_triggers.title: Track triggers
track_triggers.desc: Note what helps or hurts your nights to spot patterns.

address_disruptors.title: Tackle disruptions
address_disruptors.desc: Reduce pain, noise, light, or worries that fragment sleep.

consult_if_pain.title: Check pain or discomfort
consult_if_pain.desc: If pain or breathing issues wake you, talk with a professional.

morning_light.title: Morning light
morning_light.desc: Get bright light within an hour of waking to anchor your rhythm.

activity_breaks.title: Movement breaks
activity_breaks.desc: Short walks or stretches through the day boost energy later.

consider_medical.title: Check ongoing sleepiness
consider_medical.desc: If you’re very sleepy despite time in bed, consider a medical check.

keep_it_up.title: Keep your current wind-down
keep_it_up.desc: Your evening routine works—keep repeating it.

screens_off_60.title: Screens off 60 minutes before bed
screens_off_60.desc: Shift to low light and calmer activities the last hour.

limit_caffeine.title: Limit caffeine after lunch
limit_caffeine.desc: Stop caffeine 6–8 hours before bed to protect sleep pressure.

no_alcohol_late.title: Skip late alcohol
no_alcohol_late.desc: Avoid evening alcohol to prevent shallow, fragmented sleep.

keep_cool_dark.title: Cool, dark room
keep_cool_dark.desc: Blackout curtains and a slight drop in temperature help quality.

test_blackout.title: Test blackout and dim lights
test_blackout.desc: Use masks or blackout to cut light leaks.

noise_control.title: Quiet the room
noise_control.desc: Earplugs, white noise, or steady fan sounds reduce wake-ups.

try_new_pillow.title: Try a pillow that fits you
try_new_pillow.desc: A supportive pillow can reduce aches and tossing.

cooler_temp.title: Cooler bedroom
cooler_temp.desc: Aim slightly cooler than daytime for better sleep depth.

side_sleep.title: Sleep on your side
side_sleep.desc: Side-sleeping can reduce snoring and breathing pauses.

reduce_evening_alcohol.title: Reduce evening alcohol
reduce_evening_alcohol.desc: Alcohol relaxes airways and can worsen snoring.

consider_gp_check.title: Talk to a doctor if snoring is heavy
consider_gp_check.desc: Persistent loud snoring or pauses should be checked.
